title: Tuesday, 4th April, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM11:01am

Morning

PM11:01am

Those joining us on the right...

PM11:01am

I think this might be your moment

11:01 am
PM11:02am

The day has perhaps arrived

PM11:02am

When you can take the lead

PM11:02am

Fill the pink space

11:02 am
PM11:02am

Tell Bryce and I what we should be writing about

PM11:02am

Because

PM11:02am

To be honest

11:02 am
PM11:03am

BE11:03am

PM11:03am

11:03 am
PM11:03am

And yes there is ASOS of course

PM11:03am

Or perhaps we could just run a Sudoku on this side of the page. That's what saved newspapers last time around.

11:03 am
PM11:04am

Smart idea

PM11:04am

And if that doesn't work, we can give DVDs of old films away

undefined
11:04 am
PM11:05am

But let's try our best Bryce

BE11:05am

Talk on the right for Atkins already.

PM11:05am

Noted here yesterday, by your good self

11:05 am
PM11:06am

Best you didn't think the punters would be proved right so quickly

BE11:06am

Well .... Bid rumour was lying there for anyone to pick up all of yesterday morning, but I guess it's nice of Bloomberg and etc to give us a nod.

PM11:06am

Ah, they gave us a nod? Didn't see that -- but welcome

11:06 am
WS Atkins PLC (ATK:LSE): Last: 1,963, up 13.32 (+0.68%), High: 1,986, Low: 1,937, Volume: 453.95k
PM11:07am

What was that at the start of yesterday's session?

BE11:07am

Pity we didn't get the name of the bidder. Particularly since it was SNC, whose takeover interest in UK companies has leaked before.

11:07 am
BE11:07am

Sorry, I should say alleged takeover interest. You'll remember they went after Wood about 18 months ago, allegedly.

BE11:08am

Potential for a counter? Hmm ........

BE11:08am

Never say never, but 13 times EBITDA is quite toppy.

11:09 am
BE11:09am

The usual names were chucked about at the end of yesterday -- as in Fluor, Jacobs, that weird N2F Hill private thing.

BE11:10am

... whatever it's called. You know the one.

PM11:10am

I do, but cant remember how to spell it

11:10 am
BE11:10am

But as noted yesterday, Atkins has been advertising itself to potential buyers for some time.

BE11:10am

In that context, this feels more like the end of the process than the start.

BE11:11am

Canaccord incoming.

11:11 am
BE11:11am

Such an offer has been well telegraphed by SNC management. SNC has been
vocal about wanting to acquire a company that would increase its exposure to the
infrastructure and power markets and diversify it into Europe and/or Asia. Management
has also stated that it wanted a business that provided mostly services to offset the
growth it sees in the Canadian lump-sum, fixed price infrastructure business. With the
exception of adding meaningful Asian exposure, we believe Atkins meets all of these
requirements.

BE11:11am

SNC's proposed offer equates to an 11x EV/EBITDA (TTM to Mar. 2017) multiple, before
considering any cost synergies. We view this as an attractive acquisition multiple given
peers, WSP Global (WSP-TSX : C$47.08 Ι BUY) and Stantec (STN-TSX/NYSE : C$34.62 Ι
HOLD), trade at 11.2x and 12.0x trailing EBITDA. Based on precedent transactions, we
believe cost synergies of between C$55 million and C$125 million could be realized,
potentially lowering the acquisition EV/EBITDA multiple to between 9.3x and 7.8x.
On an earnings basis, the SNC offer implies 17.5x 2017E (March) EPS, pre synergies.
This compares unfavorably to SNC's multiple of 16.0x trailing EPS (December)

BE11:12am

We believe SNC will need to issue equity to finance any acquisition of Atkins. At the end
of Q4/2016, SNC had net cash of $695 million. However, we do not believe any of that
cash is freehold so, in our view, it is best to assume the company has zero net debt. Pro
forma TTM EBITDA (ex. concessions) would be C$690 (C$826 on 2017E). If SNC wanted
to lever-up to 3.0x debt-to-EBITDA it would imply C$1.4 billion in additional equity (C$1.0
billion using 2017E EBITDA) would be needed. Our analysis assumes no concession
investments are disposed of to finance the deal. SNC management has stated that it
does not intend to sell its stake in Highway 407.

11:12 am
BE11:13am

Nearly everyone on the Atkins side is restricted, apart from Jefferies, which as we noted yesterday dropped coverage on Friday.

BE11:13am

There is Citi, though. Which we quoted in the paper overnight.

BE11:13am

11:13 am
BE11:14am

Which looks fair enough.

undefined
PM11:14am

What else was going on yesterday?

11:14 am
PM11:14am

I see most of the sellside joining your view on Imagination

PM11:15am

"Game over" says Deutsche

BE11:15am

As an investment case, certainly.

11:15 am
PM11:15am

Apple walking away threatens Imagination’s future –retain Sell________________________________________________________________________________________________________________Deutsche Bank AG/LondonDeutsche Bank does and seeks to do business with companies covered in its research reports. Thus, investors should be aware that the firm may have a conflict of interest that could affect the objectivity of this report. Investors should consider this report as only a single factor in making their investment decision. DISCLOSURES AND ANALYST CERTIFICATIONS ARE LOCATED IN APPENDIX 1. MCI (P) 057/04/2016.Price at 3 Apr 2017 (GBP)103.00Price Target (GBP)76.0052-week range (GBP)291.50 -103.00Johannes SchallerResearch Analyst(+49) 69 910-31731johannes.schaller@db.comRobert SandersResearch Analyst(+44) 20 754-58394rob.sanders@db.comKey changesTarget Price170.00 to 76.00↓-55.3%Source: Deutsche BankPrice/price relative801201602002402803204/1410/144/1510/154/1610/16ImaginationFTSE 100 INDEX (Rebased) Performance (%)1m3m12mAbsolute-60.5-58.9-45.8FTSE 100 INDEX-0.72.019.1Source: Deutsche BankValuation; risksWe cut our target from 170p to 76p valuing IMG’s continued business at ~2.5x CY18E ex-Apple EV/sales. This is a blend of the ~4x EV/sales multiple pre FY/16 and the 1x IMG paid for MIPS in 2012. We note that 2.5x already implies a return towards mid-twenties operating margin versus DBe loss making ex Apple. Risks: A new agreement with Apple or successfullitigation over patent infringement; significantshare gains at other customers; FX.Yesterday,Imagination announced that Apple will stop using its PowerVR graphics IP and cease royalty payments within the next 15-24 months. We have raised concerns over IMG’s relationship with its largest customer several times in the past, following significant hiring by Apple into its own graphics department, and see our cautious view confirmed. With IMG’s ex-Apple business also challenged and heavily loss-making, we believe a fire sale of the company is the only option left for management and investors. However, valuation prospects for the remaining asset barely offer much upside but some potential downside risk, in our view. Retain Sell.

PM11:15am

Just feels harsh, even if it's the right advice

PM11:15am

A fire sale now seems inevitable but the price may disappoint –SellAbout 2/3of IMG’s 1200engineers are currently employed in its PVR division with management noting that little direct cost is associated with Apple. This highlights a key problem. IP development is a high fixed-costbusiness and reducing PVR headcount significantly following the Apple loss will make IMG’s offering significantly less competitive. Even ex-Apple, PVR will still account for ~40% of royalties with MIPS ~60% but we expect share losses in both divisions to ARM going forward even with current R&D budgets andstruggle to see a standalone future for the company. We believe a fire sale of the remaining business is ultimately the only strategic option left, similar to what MIPS did when it sold itself to Imagination 5 years ago. Having said that, IMG bought MIPS for 1x EV/sales and applying this multiple to IMG’s ex-Apple revenue base would only result in est.fair value of 30p per share. At a historic 4x IMG EV/sales multiple, fairvalue would come out around 122p. We apply a 50/50 probability to both valuation scenarios and derive a target of 76p –Sell

11:15 am
BE11:16am

I mean, I wish Imagination luck in its contract renegotiation with the world's largest company and-or litigation battle.

BE11:16am

I'd just not want to hold the stock while it does either of these things.

BE11:16am

Numis, I think, had a sensible run though the options. Hold on.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

IMG is in discussion with Apple on potential alternative commercial arrangements for
the current license and royalty agreement. We would speculate that an option under
consideration would be a one-off payment for a perpetual license to the patent portfolio.
While it might appear that IMG is in a weak position, we would argue the opposite given
the importance of the GPU to a number of Apple products, most importantly the iPhone.
● In a doomsday scenario, where no agreement is reached, IMG's next step would likely
be to sue Apple for patent infringement once the existing agreements roll off in late
2018. There have been precedents for very large settlements in similar cases, including
Marvell paying $750m to Carnegie Mellon in 2016 for patent rights relating to hard disk
technology and RIM paying $613m in 2006 for rights relating to a backup system

BE11:18am

Sorry for the lumpy formatting.

BE11:19am

And Credit Suisse is doing the riskiest kind of knife catching (or closing a short while pointing out that they were sellers beforehand, whichever).

11:19 am
PM11:19am

hehe

BE11:19am

Upgrade from UP to Neutral, TP lowered to 100p. Post the announcement
around Apple moving away from using IMG graphics to its own independent
solution, we now assume Apple contribution (~50% of IMG group revenues
in FY17) to decline by 60% in FY19 (year ending Apr-2019) before falling to
zero by FY20. Small part of this would be offset by design wins at
Spreadtrum and in areas outside of Mobile, but this would imply that IMG
sales will decline from £136mn in FY17E to £80mn by FY20E, making the
EBIT profit of £26mn in FY17E turn into £24mn loss by FY20E. With Apple
risks now having played out (something we have been flagging recently,
although we only expected scoping down of existing agreement), we believe
there could be some interest in IMG assets (graphics technology, IP and
patents). As such, we upgrade to Neutral with TP of 100p (down from 180p).

BE11:20am

Our TP of 100p is based on 4.0x EV/sales on
FY20 estimates by when we assume Apple-related sales to decline to zero.
This would imply an EV of £320mn for IMG assuming net debt of £25mn for
year ending Apr-17. What is interesting to note here is that CEVA (another IP
company) currently trades on 6x FY3 EV/sales (consensus), ARM was
acquired by Softbank last year on 16x FY3 EV/sales (consensus), and MIPS
(another IP company) itself was acquired by IMG for $100mn in Dec-12
(implying LTM EV/sales of 1.2x) but MIPS also managed to sell its patents
separately to a patent holding company for $350mn. Given IMG's graphics
offering and its portfolio of patents around it, we believe there is an increased
probability of M&A interest especially from China

11:20 am
BE11:20am

....... which is reasonable but, as we said yesterday, isn't really an investment case.

PM11:20am

Still, clear deadcat move this morning

BE11:20am

And finally Jefferies .....

11:20 am
Imagination Technologies Group PLC (IMG:LSE): Last: 112.65, up 9.65 (+9.37%), High: 114.25, Low: 85.17, Volume: 9.58m
BE11:21am

.... because the note I meant to quote earlier was from Jefferies not Numis, so instead I'm giving you both.

BE11:22am

Scenario 1 Simple Cessation: The vanilla version sees Apple royalties swiftly decline
as new products move to in-house (or other) sourcing from say 2QCY2018 (the earliest
interpretation of 5Qs, i.e. worst case) and IMG collects a dwindling base of older units as
they roll off. FY19E would thus be the first year affected, with FY20E mostly ‘post Apple’. This
timetable could be a year later on the longer timescale for replacement. This becomes our
base case and implies looming losses in FY20E, and perhaps before, plus a financing crunch
unless debt can be paid down before covenants are breached. FY17E appears on track, and
we haven’t changed FY18E estimates except for currency updating.
S2 bargaining bully: Assumes that Apple is actually flexing its muscle to bargain for a
lower royalty rate. How low would presumably be set by whatever can keep IMG on life
support – not a happy picture, unless IMG actually has strong IP and Apple is bluffing.
S3 court clash: If Apple can’t replace IMG without infringing its IP, IMG can fight, and has
reserved its right to do so. Proving infringement, and fighting the case could be expensive
and difficult for such a David vs. Goliath battle. Financing it would require backers confident
of the strength of the case.
S4 takeover trickery: A Byzantine analysis would have Apple intent on taking over
Imagination for PowerVR, and using the warning of cessation to depress its prey’s valuation
(and emphasize its dependence on Apple) before pouncing. A version of this would see
Apple standing by to acquire IMG’s IP in any future crisis – perhaps at least providing a
safety net to value. This seems a long shot.

Lumpy formatting again though. Sorry.

Anyway, folk seem to be interested in AstraZeneca. Don't know why. Risky time to do so ahead of the Mystic results due midyear.

11:27 am

BE11:27am

(@ROTR: if I knew, I'd tell you. I don't.)

PM11:32am

ASOS?

11:31 am
BE11:32am

ASOS!

ASOS PLC (ASC:LSE): Last: 5,725, down 252 (-4.22%), High: 5,820, Low: 5,536, Volume: 733.54k
PM11:32am

Lot of fretting about margins here

11:32 am
PM11:32am

I thought this was already signalled?

BE11:32am

Yep. But sales guidance up, PBT guidance unchanged, shares down.

PM11:33am

Interim statement here http://www.investe...1704040700084477B/

11:32 am
BE11:33am

Noises about investment and suchlike clearly not well enough flagged.

BE11:33am

Shares priced for upgrades that won't arrive today.

PM11:01am

Welcome to Markets Live

11:33 am
BE11:34am

Barclays incoming, so summarise the figures.

BE11:34am

ASOS has reported 1H17 revenues of £912m, 1% ahead of company consensus £901m and Barclays £899m. P2 revenues (two months to end Feb) came in 4% ahead of consensus, growing 40% vs consensus 35%. By segment in P2: UK retail sales +16% (Barclays 18%, consensus 18%), US retail sales +54% (Barclays 57%, cons 55%), EU retail sales +46% (Barclays 40%, cons 43%), RoW retail sales +80% (Barclays 45%, cons 45%). So RoW has essentially driven this beat (we presume Russia and Australia were a big part of this). The UK has slowed very slightly (was +18% in P1) and this will remain a focus.

BE11:34am

Retail GMs came in at 47.0%, down 40bps yoy (was down 30bps in P1, we had 40bps down). 1H PBT of £27.3m is in line with consensus £27.1m and slightly below our £28m.
Guidance increased at revenue line: ASOS now expects 30-35% reported growth in FY17E vs 25-30% previously. Reuters consensus is 31% growth, we have 33% growth. So this is to some degree factored in by consensus but still positive that management feels confident enough to raise top line guidance at this stage. Guidance remains unchanged at the profit line (“PBT broadly in line with market consensus”. We believe this means management is comfortable with PBT of c£80m (Reuters consensus is £81m). So despite a stronger top line, management is not sanctioning a profit upgrade – we believe this is due to Eurohub 2 transition costs, sourcing inflation (both FX + ethical focus we believe), absorption of change in Australian sales tax, plus national minimum wage. Capex guidance unchanged at £150-170m – expect more colour on US warehouse at presentation.

11:34 am
BE11:34am

And Morgan Stanley.

BE11:35am

We already forecast 33% growth as the H1 results would only require 24% revenue growth in H2 and even though comps get tougher, it seemed excessively conservative. Our expectation implies revenue growth of 28% which looks more reasonable. Just like at the P1 update, the 5%-point comes without a raise in PBT, perhaps as the growth is increasingly coming from RoW through customer proposition improvements.

PM11:35am

Followers of this thing are so demanding

11:35 am
BE11:35am

The shares have had a strong run into results and are trading at a premium to peers, so they could be under a bit of pressure given the lack of PBT upgrade. ASOS is trading on 1.9x 2018e EV/Sales, 24.3x EV/EBITDA and 54.7x P/E vs Zalando on 1.7x, 18x and 41.5x and YNAP on 1.2x, 12.1x and 28.6x

BE11:35am

I mean, though. 55x for a frock shop in a fragmenting market.

PM11:36am

Yeah, i know

11:35 am
BE11:36am

Asos is clearly a good, possibly even great, frock shop.

PM11:36am

Ads for online frocks pasted on every railway platform

BE11:36am

Yep, mostly following the Boohoo model -- as in, be smaller and push unbranded fast fashion.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

There are hundreds of them now. And given apparel spending is heading lower, in the UK at least, I'm struggling to see how they can all do high teens revenue growth per quarter.

PM11:38am

And yet things like Zalando trading close to 12 month highs...

PM11:38am

Zalando up almost 3% in Germany today

11:38 am
PM11:38am

(Rocket isn't)

BE11:38am

RBC to wrap up the theme.

BE11:38am

Overall this is a very strong top-line performance for ASOS, particularly when compared with Next’s recent online growth and outlook comments,
however once again it shows how difficult it is to achieve both sales and margin higher than consensus expectations.
H1 sales growth ahead of expectations
Revenue was 2% ahead of our forecast driven by a stronger than expected performance by the Rest of the World region. In the UK, sales grew by 18%
during H1 in line with our forecast while International grew by 42% in constant currency (vs RBC at 39%). The International beat was driven by RoW
sales which grew +53% in ccy vs RBC at +43%, driven by Russia and Australia. The US grew sales in ccy at 39% broadly in line with our +40% estimate
and Europe +36% in ccy vs RBC at +37%.
Gross margin lower than expected.
The gross margin in H1 was -60bps vs our estimate of -10bps owing to prior year price cuts in the EU and current year price cuts in the US. Also ASOS
has invested in its UK loyalty scheme. The combined impact of these investments was partially offset by higher full price sales mix and lower
markdown on clearance stock.
Our view: Outperform
We believe that ASOS’ guidance for 20-25% revenue growth this year is conservative on account of recent and upcoming proposition enhancements,
particularly in the US and Europe. The expansion into sportswear, focus on mobile and new brand additions should also support growth throughout
FY17. ASOS trades at 2.5x CY17 EV/Sales falling to 2x in for CY18e.

11:39 am
BE11:39am

Yeah, lumpy formatting. Sorry. Again.

undefined
BE11:40am

11:40 am

BE11:41am

11:41 am

BE11:42am

11:42 am
BE11:42am

We have raised EPS forecasts by c.10% in 2017E and 15% in 2018E as our house price inflation forecasts increase to +3% in 2017 and +1% in 2018, as economic forecasts improve. But we are more cautious on the sector now in spite of higher target prices due to recent share price gains. We prefer the growers who can offset expected margin pressure with volume growth, to the returners. Buy rated stocks are Bellway, Gleeson and Redrow (from Hold).

BE11:43am

That! That's what they're telling us.

BE11:43am

Our three preferred stocks (Bellway, Gleeson and Redrow) are all growers rather than returners. As we
expect house price inflation to slow materially in 2018 to 1%, the growers have the best chance of keeping profit growth going, in spite of likely margin pressure. Persimmon and Berkeley have been downgraded to Hold (from Buy) on valuation. Barratt (Sell, TP 492p) remains our least preferred stock as its short landbank makes its dividend less sustainable under stress than for the other returners.

11:42 am
PM11:43am

Fair enough

PM11:44am

What the hell is this

11:44 am
PM11:44am

Blue Star Capital

PM11:45am

Deciding the laws of demand and supply are upside down

PM11:45am

"Blue Star Capital plc (AIM: BLU), the investing company with a focus on technology and its applications within media and gaming, announces an update following its announcement on 2 March 2017 regarding its further investment in SatoshiPay ("Investment") and issue of 268,213,880 new ordinary shares of Blue Star to FastForward as consideration for the Investment (the "Announcement").

11:45 am
PM11:45am

At the time of entering into the SPA regarding the Investment, as a result of the Consideration Shares to be issued to FastForward comprising approximately 21.7 percent. of the issued share capital of the Company, the Directors of Blue Star considered that it was in the best interests of shareholders for the Consideration Shares to be subject to a staged lock-in agreement over a period of 9 months ("lock-in arrangements"). Following the Announcement and completion of the Investment, the Directors believe that the lock-in arrangements may have led to the share price of Blue Star under-performing compared to the Director's expectations whilst shareholders and potential new investors wait for each lock-in period to end. Taking this into account and the strong interest in the Company's placing of new ordinary shares in January 2017, the Directors have agreed that, subject to the broker finalising arrangements to place out the existing Consideration Shares to a variety of investors on terms that the Directors consider are acceptable, the lock-in arrangements may be terminated. The Directors believe that this will be in the best interests of shareholders. The Directors will provide an update in the event that the existing Consideration Shares are successfully placed-out with new shareholders.

BE11:46am

(@Littleclenches, ROTR: sorry, you misunderstand me. Mention of Old Mutual was in reference to a speculative run last month, which was curtailed by South African politics again. Today's move is of course on S&P cutting SA to junk, etc.)

PM11:49am

11:49 am

11:51 am
PM11:51am

Anyway, I'm told the core portfolio businesses are all in good shape

PM11:51am

But there is a need to put some of the laggards out of their misery

PM11:51am

And that will feed through into NAV write-downs, i guess

will they be festive or funereal? We expect that it will be much easier to write-down/writeoff/slate for disposal some of the strugglers in the portfolio (RFB, Cryoxtract, TTS) than to

11:52 am

We haven’t been able to discuss strategy with new CEO Jill Smith since former
CEO Chris Silva’s exit 13/3/17, perhaps because of the nearness of results as above. Her
familiarity with the portfolio as a one-year board member should enable her to make quick
decisions, albeit potentially making it difficult to change decisions she had participated in.

BE11:53am

In our Sep 2015 report, our raised price target and Buy
rating were predicated on four hurdles: value from a disposal, third party investment,
commercial traction, or new disruptive subsidiaries. Only the last and least quantitative has
shown any progress. ALM’s portfolio values seem high versus peers, setting a high bar.

BE11:53am

The largest investments, Spin Transfer (STT), may need
cash reload, ideally with external validation, SciFluor's mid-year SF0166 Ph I/IIa should justify
funding a larger Ph. IIb (or could fail), but like Precision Biopsy seems fairly valued at this
early stage. Federated Wireless is the great hope but the path to monetisation and its timing
is unclear to us.

11:53 am
BE11:53am

On a 47% premium to est. GSOAV (Group Subsidiary Ownership-Adj.
Value) adjusted for 'own' cash after the $81m Dec 16 raise, ALM is expensive vs. peers. We
see initial downside risk to values from a clear-out on results, while none of the promise
(mainly Federated Wireless) appears close to validating events. Given the already significant
valuations of portfolio companies, we set a target based on a 10% to GSOAV & cash, at
254p, pending FY16 details and the new CEO’s plans.

11:59 am
BE11:59am

Here's Cantor.

BE12:00pm

Today’s update covers the 26 weeks to end March (H1). Total sales were down 1.4% to £106.5m. LFL sales have fallen by 2.2% on an underlying basis (1.9% reported) adjusting for the timing of Easter and an additional trading day. This follows the underlying decline of 0.3% after the first 13 weeks (Q1) implying that the most recent 13 weeks (Q2) have seen LFLs down by c.4.1%. We understand that trade in January was tough, was a little better in February before picking up again in March. We believe the exit rate was closer to 0% to -2% LFL. Comparatives from last year were relatively strong helped by the growth in housing transactions ahead of the Stamp duty change with LFLs over the first 26 weeks of FY’16 up by 5.0% underlying implying a 2 year run rate of +2.8%. The underlying Q2 comp was +5.5%. Looking ahead comparatives strengthen further in Q3 (+6.2% or +5.7% Easter timing adjusted) before softening to +1.4% in Q4.

BE12:00pm

Forecasts unchanged for now – Lower operating costs (principally staff bonus) will help to offset the sales shortfall and management are confident that FY’17 PBT will be within the range of market expectations (£21.0-£22.3m). Having taken a prudent stance back in January when we trimmed our FY’17 PBT forecast to £21.5m (EPS: 8.6p) from £22.5m (EPS: 9.2p) previously we are leaving our forecasts unchanged today. We will review following the interims in May. Prior to today’s update consensus stood at £21.8m (EPS 8.8p). We maintain our BUY recommendation with a target price of 107p.

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

There is still a good long term story – After a relatively quiet three years, Topps Tiles can now be viewed again as having a credible roll-out strategy. It plans to open c.15 stores pa (10 core stores have been opened in H1/17 with 3 closures) with a two year cash payback target. This is towards a long term target of 450 stores from the current total of 358 stores, including 15 boutique stores and plans to refurbish up to 15 stores pa. It should also be able to further grow trade sales, which currently accounts for over 50% of revenues, in particular, to the small business segment. Combined with these developments, it is further refining and broadening the assortment to include a more fashionable and innovative range, while withdrawing from its under-performing wood offer. We note the encouraging news today that the new enhanced wood effect tile ranges and XL tiles continue to trade well. The reduction in sales from the exit of wood flooring impacted sales by c.1%.
